In Hinduism ''[[kāma]]'' is pleasurable, sexual love, personified by the god [[Kamadeva]]. For many Hindu schools it is the third end (''[[artha]]'') in life . [[Kamadeva]] and are the [[divine couple]] who are '''Hindu love Gods'''. Kaama is often pictured holding a bow of [[sugarcane]] and an [[arrow]] of [[flowers]]: he may ride upon a great parrot. He is usually accompanied by his consort [[Rati]] and his companion [[Vasanta]], lord of the [[spring (season)|spring]] season. Stone images of Kaama and Rati can be seen on the door of the Chenna Keshava temple at [[Belur]], in [[Karnataka]], [[India]]. [[Maara]] is another name for Kaama.
